content:
I've been working hard trying to finish two papers before the end of the year. But I have to goof off a little or I'll go crazy. So I wrote a quick intro to this:

  • The algebraic K-theory of the integers.

Basic idea:

The category of groups Zn\mathbb{Z}^nZn and isomorphisms between these is symmetric monoidal under ⊕\oplus⊕. You can build a space out of simplexes where the 0-simplexes are objects of this category, the 1-simplexes are morphisms, the 2-simplexes are commutative triangles, the 3-simplexes are commutative tetrahedra, and so on forever. This space has an operation, coming from ⊕\oplus⊕, that obeys the commutative monoid axioms up to homotopy. If you 'group complete' this space by throwing in formal inverses, you get a space that's an abelian group up to homotopy. It's called the algebraic KKK-theory spectrum of the integers.
I see a lot of questions -- how rhetorical are they?

John Baez said:

I've been working hard trying to finish two papers before the end of the year. But I have to goof off a little or I'll go crazy.

This is exceptionally relatable to me right now :joy:

Ian Coley said:

I see a lot of questions -- how rhetorical are they?

There are 3 questions. The first two I'd like answers to:

Is this right? Are these the right homomorphisms?

The third is a puzzle that apparently everyone is too shy to publicly answer on the blog:

Notice anything interesting about these numbers less than and relatively prime to 24?

which is sad because it denies me the chance to say something interesting.
Are you looking for "they're almost all prime" for that last question? :joy:
Yes, and that would start another conversation.
(On the blog.)
This one of the famous properties of the numbers 24... and 30.
Alright, as you wish..!
Okay, you gave me the excuse to talk about some weird stuff.
I'm trying to learn some stuff about the algebraic K-theory groups Kn(Z)\mathrm{K}_n(\mathbb{Z})Kn​(Z) and stable homotopy groups πns\pi_n^sπns​.
I'm interested in the case where n=4m−1n = 4m-1n=4m−1, since this is when Bernoulli numbers show up, and some other fun stuff.

There's a certain chunk of πns\pi_n^sπns​ called Im(J)n\mathrm{Im}(J)_nIm(J)n​, the image of the J-homomorphism, and Adams showed that when n=4m−1n = 4m-1n=4m−1 it's a cyclic group whose order is connected to Bernoulli numbers.
The Wikipedia link states the facts pretty clearly. Using my notation, the order of Im(J)4m−1\mathrm{Im}(J)_{4m-1}Im(J)4m−1​ is the denominator of
B2m/4m B_{2m}/4m B2m​/4m
where B2mB_{2m}B2m​ is a Bernoulli number.
Here are some examples:

m=1m = 1m=1, B2m=1/6B_{2m} = 1/6B2m​=1/6, so the denominator of B2m/4mB_{2m}/4mB2m​/4m is 4×6=244 \times 6 = 244×6=24, so Z/24≅Im(J)3⊆π3s \mathbb{Z}/24 \cong \mathrm{Im}(J)_3 \subseteq \pi_3^sZ/24≅Im(J)3​⊆π3s​. In this case Z/24\mathbb{Z}/24Z/24 is all of the stable homotopy group π3s\pi_3^sπ3s​.

m=2m = 2m=2, B2m=−1/30B_{2m} = -1/30B2m​=−1/30, so the denominator of B2m/4mB_{2m}/4mB2m​/4m is 8×30=2408 \times 30 = 2408×30=240, so Z/240≅Im(J)7⊆π7s \mathbb{Z}/240 \cong \mathrm{Im}(J)_7 \subseteq \pi_7^sZ/240≅Im(J)7​⊆π7s​. In this case Z/240\mathbb{Z}/240Z/240 is all of the stable homotopy group π7s\pi_7^sπ7s​.

m=3m = 3m=3, B2m=1/42B_{2m} = 1/42B2m​=1/42, so the denominator of B2m/4mB_{2m}/4mB2m​/4m is 12×42=50412 \times 42 = 50412×42=504, so Z/504≅Im(J)11⊆π11s \mathbb{Z}/504 \cong \mathrm{Im}(J)_{11} \subseteq \pi_{11}^sZ/504≅Im(J)11​⊆π11s​. In this case Z/504\mathbb{Z}/504Z/504 is all of the stable homotopy group π11s\pi_{11}^sπ11s​.
I have no idea why Im(J)\mathrm{Im}(J)Im(J) works this way, and that's what I'm trying to understand.
But anyway, it looks like Bernoulli numbers might be a bit of a red herring, since all we care about is the denominators of Bernoulli numbers.
Adams proved these were connected to Im(J)\mathrm{Im}(J)Im(J) using Von Staudt's theorem.
This theorem says the denominator of B2mB_{2m}B2m​ is the product of all primes ppp such that p−1p-1p−1 divides 2m2m2m.
Let's test it out.
m=1m = 1m=1. The primes ppp such that p−1p-1p−1 divides 2m=22m = 22m=2 are 2 and 3, so the denominator is 2×3=62 \times 3 = 62×3=6.
m=2m = 2m=2. The primes ppp such that p−1p - 1p−1 divides 2m=42m = 42m=4 are 2, 3 and 5 so the denominator is 2×3×5=30 2 \times 3 \times 5 = 302×3×5=30.
m=3m = 3 m=3. The primes ppp such that p−1p -1 p−1 divides 2m=62m = 62m=6 are 2, 3 and 7 so the denominator is 2×3×7=42 2 \times 3 \times 7 = 42 2×3×7=42.
Yup, it's working. So maybe Bernoulli numbers are less important than these products of primes.
Note that the order of Im(J)n\mathrm{Im}(J)_nIm(J)n​ winds up being a power of two times a bunch of distinct odd primes.
